== Causes == [[Image:Kuwadzana open drain.JPG|250px|thumb|left|An open drain in [[Kuwadzana]] township, [[Harare]] in 2004. By 2008 drains such as this were carrying sewage from burst sewage pipes and [[feces]] washed out of the neighbouring areas as the urban sanitation system collapsed. This contributed to the rapid spread of the cholera outbreak.]] The principal cause of the outbreak is lack of access to [[potable water|safe water]] in urban areas and communities. A unique feature of Zimbabwe is that its two main cities are located on watershed divides, which means that the water draining out of the city flows into the drinking water sources, all of which are physically located downstream of these return flows.<ref name="environment.co.za">http://www.environment.co.za/documents/water/KeynoteAddressCSIR2008.pdf</ref> This is exacerbated by the collapse of the urban [[water supply]],<ref name="Zimbabwe's cholera epidemic hits 10,000 ">{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/zimbabwe/3536824/Zimbabwes-cholera-epidemic-hits-10000.html|title=Zimbabwe's cholera epidemic hits 10,000 |date=01 Dec 2008|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=2008-12-02 | location=London | first=Peta | last=Thornycroft}}</ref> [[sanitation]]<ref name=collapse/> and [[Waste management|garbage collection systems]],<ref name=storm/> along with the onset of the rainy season leading to [[faeces]] with cholera bacteria being washed into water sources, in particular public drains,<ref name=rain/> as well as providing readily available but contaminated water.<ref name=coping>{{cite news|url=http://www.icrc.org/web/eng/siteeng0.nsf/html/zimbabwe-feature-261108?opendocument|title=Zimbabwe: coping with the cholera outbreak|date=26 November 2008|publisher=|accessdate=2008-12-03}}</ref> Due to a shortage of purification chemicals, such as chlorine, the capital city of [[Harare]] stopped receiving piped water on 1 December 2008.<ref name=mobilize/> By that date, many suburbs had not had any water supply for much longer.<ref name=3000dead/> On 4 December 2008, the Zimbabwe deputy minister for water and infrastructural development stated that there were only sufficient treatment chemicals in stock nationally for twelve weeks supply.<ref name=appeal>{{cite news|url=http://africa.reuters.com/wire/news/usnL4384569.html|title=Zimbabwe appeals for donor help on cholera|date=04 Dec 2008|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=2008-12-04}}</ref> The collapse of these systems has frequently been blamed on the current [[Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe|economic crisis]].<ref name="Capital lacks clean water, cholera kills hundreds in Zimbabwe"/><ref name=oxfam/> Attempts have also been made to attribute the blame to colonial rule, although Zimbabwe had become a fully independent nation 28 years earlier, in 1980.<ref name=racist>{{cite news|url=http://www1.sundaymail.co.zw/inside.aspx?sectid=1021&cat=18|title=Water woes a creation of racist Rhodesia|date=6 December 2008|publisher=The Sunday Mail|accessdate=2008-12-07}}</ref> Many households cannot even afford sufficient fuel to boil all of their water.<ref name=oxfam2/> According to [[MÃ©decins Sans FrontiÃ¨res]], the spread of cholera from urban to rural areas from December 2008 onwards was due to infected city-dwellers visiting their families' rural homes for [[Christmas]] and the burial of infected city-dwellers in rural areas.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cholera moves to rural Zimbabwe|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7844417.stm|date=22 Jan 2009|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2009-01-22}}</ref>
The cholera epidemic in Zimbabwe has had an unusually high fatality rate. According to Oxfam, "this is due to the fact Zimbabweans are seriously weakened by hunger, HIV and AIDS".<ref name=oxfam2/>
A major contributing factor to the severity of the outbreak is the collapse of Zimbabwe's public health system, declared a national emergency on 4 December 2008.<ref name=emergency>{{cite news|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hsW9YNn1roEp0rzjeGSJo0pKcj2A|title=Zimbabwe declares cholera outbreak a national emergency|date=04 Dec 2008|publisher=AFP|accessdate=2008-12-04}}</ref> By the end of November 2008, three of Zimbabwe's four major hospitals had shut down, along with the Zimbabwe Medical School, and the fourth major hospital had two wards and no operating theatres working.<ref name=hospitals>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7714892.stm|title=The death throes of Harare's hospitals|date=7 November 2008|publisher=BBC |accessdate=2008-12-03}}</ref><ref name=hospitals2>{{cite news|url=http://www.radiovop.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4452&Itemid=755|title=Zimbabwe's Medical School Closes|date=19 November 2008|publisher=Radio VOP |accessdate=2008-12-03}}</ref> Zimbabwean hospitals still open by December 2008 lacked medicines and staff. Due to [[Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe|hyperinflation]], hospitals were not able to buy basic drugs and medicines, and the resources of even internationally-funded emergency clinics are stretched.<ref name=coping/> The ongoing political and economic crisis also contributed to the emigration of the doctors and people with medical knowledge.<ref name="Zimbabwe cholera deaths near 500 ">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7760088.stm|title=Zimbabwe cholera deaths near 500 |date=2 December 2008|publisher=BBC |accessdate=2008-12-02}}</ref> Some victims were travelling to [[Botswana]] and other neighbouring countries for treatment.<ref name="Capital lacks clean water, cholera kills hundreds in Zimbabwe">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/12/01/zimbabwe.cholera/index.html?eref=rss_world|title=Capital lacks clean water, cholera kills hundreds in Zimbabwe|date=December 1, 2008|publisher=CNN|accessdate=2008-12-02}}</ref>
== Impact == [[Image:Zimcholeracases2.png|350px|thumb|right|The spread of cholera in Zimbabwe: (top) The number of cases recorded in the most infected centres and districts, and in the remainder of each province of Zimbabwe as of 4 March 2009. (bottom) Total number of reported cases. Since totals for many districts are not updated daily, the first occurrence of a case may represent the date of the reporting of that case, not the date of infection. Data sources: [[United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]],<ref name=daily>{{cite web|last=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|first=|authorlink=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|coauthors=|title =Daily Cholera Update|work=|publisher=|date=''daily since 24 November 2008'''|url=http://ochaonline.un.org/CholeraSituation/tabid/5147/language/en-US/Default.aspx|format=|doi=|accessdate=2009-01-27}}</ref> the [[World Health Organisation]],<ref name=epidemiologicaljan03>{{cite web|last=World Health Organisation|first=|authorlink=World Health Organisation|coauthors=|title=WHO Zimbabwe Cholera Epidemiological Bulletin No. 4, 3 January 2009|work=|publisher=|date=2009-01-03|url=http://ochaonline.un.org/OchaLinkClick.aspx?link=ocha&docId=1099223|format=|doi=|accessdate=2009-01-15}}</ref> the [[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]].<ref name=ifrcrc/><ref>''[http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/retrieveattachments?openagent&shortid=CJAL-7LAP6F&file=Full_Report.pdf Zimbabwe: Cholera Outbreak]''. [[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]], 11 November 2008</ref> and news media,<ref name=collapse>{{cite news|url=http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/region/africa/081203-zimbabwe-cholera|title=Zimbabwe in collapse|date=03 Dec 2008|publisher=Radio Netherlands Worldwide|accessdate= 2008-12-03}}</ref><ref name=mobilize>{{cite news|url=http://www.zwnews.net/issuefull.cfm?ArticleID=19803|title=United Nations, Red Cross mobilize cholera relief for Zimbabwe|date=03 Dec 2008|publisher=VOA news|accessdate=2008-12-03}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name=standard>{{cite news|url=http://www.thezimbabwestandard.com/local/19302--doctors-saycholera-toll-now-800.html|title=Doctors Say Cholera Toll Now 800|date=29 Nov 2008|publisher=The Standard (Zimbabwe)|accessdate=2008-12-10}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name=newzimbabwe/><ref>''[http://ochaonline.un.org/OchaLinkClick.aspx?link=ocha&docId=1095879 Zimbabwe Humanitarian Situation Report On Cholera Outbreak]'', United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, 12 September 2008.</ref><ref name=redalert>{{cite news|url= http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23598833-details/Red+alert+as+cholera+crisis+spreads+to+Zimbabwe's+neighbours/article.do|title=Red alert as cholera crisis spreads to Zimbabwe's neighbours|date=9 Dec 2009|publisher=Evening Standard (UK)| accessdate=2008-12-09}}</ref>]] The outbreak began in [[Chitungwiza]] on 27 August 2008, with the first case in Harare reported four days later. The next district to report cholera was [[Kariba]] on 21 September 2008, with [[Makonde (District)|Makonde]] following on 3 October 2008.<ref name=daily/> Thereafter, the disease spread to reach all of [[Provinces of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe's ten provinces]].<ref name=daily/><ref name=storm>{{cite news|url= http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=81699|title=ZIMBABWE: Cholera feeds off a perfect storm|date=27 November 2008<!-- 2008-->| publisher=IRIN|accessdate=2008-12-03}}</ref> The attack rate was highest in Beitbridge, Chegutu, Mudzi and Zvimba Districts (above 1,000 cases per 100,000 people or 1.0%).<ref name=epidemiologicaljan03/>
The number of infected cases reported by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs escalated from 30 on 1 September 2008<ref name=sanitation>{{cite news|url=http://sanitationupdates.wordpress.com/2008/09/08/zimbabwe-harare-residents-slam-zinwa-after-fatal-cholera-outbreak/|title=Zimbabwe, Harare: Residents Slam ZINWA After Fatal Cholera Outbreak|date=8 Sept 2008 | publisher=Sanitation Updates|accessdate=2008-12-10}}</ref> to 15,572 by 10 December.<ref name=newzimbabwe>{{cite news|url= http://www.newzimbabwe.com/pages/health12.19130.html|title=Cholera death toll tops 746|date=10 Dec 2008|publisher=New Zimbabwe.com| accessdate=2008-12-03}}</ref> It was argued by some agencies that the reported number of cases probably under-estimated the extent of the outbreak, since many people were unlikely to have reached the clinics or treatment where the numbers were recorded. According to the Red Cross, around 46% of reported deaths occur en route to clinics and hospitals.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.zimbabwejournalists.com/story.php?art_id=5171&cat=1|title=Zimbabwe rainy season increasing cholera risk says British Red Cross|date=14 Jan 2009|publisher=Zimbabwe Journalists|accessdate=2009-01-15}}</ref> The head of the British [[Department for International Development]] in Harare said that "there are probably twice as many people with cholera as turn up for treatment."<ref name=overwhelmed>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article5315386.ece|title=Health clinics overwhelmed by cholera cases in Zimbabwe|date=10 Dec 2008|publisher= The Times (UK)|accessdate=2008-12-10 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Fletcher}}</ref>
The case fatality rate for the outbreak was higher than expected for such outbreaks, although it began declining by January 2009.<ref name=epidemiologicaljan03/> Official estimates of fatalities have run from 484 to 800, since the outbreak in August 2008,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/32e1d0aa-c076-11dd-9559-000077b07658.html|title=Cholera outbreak kills 484 in Zimbabwe|date=2 Dec 2008|publisher=Financial Times (UL)|accessdate=2008-12-02}}</ref> with an upper estimate of 3,000 from an anonymous senior official in the Ministry of Health and Child Welfare.<ref name=3000dead>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/3000-dead-from-cholera-in-zimbabwe-1035149.html|title=3,000 dead from cholera in Zimbabwe|date=26 November 2008|publisher=The Independent (UK)|accessdate=2008-12-03 | location=London | first=Basildon | last=Peta}}</ref> Fatality rates varied from 2.5% in Harare to 18% in Chitungwiza.<ref name=bulletin12dec/> In [[Harare]], the crisis reached the extent that the city council offered free graves to cholera victims.<ref name=rain>{{cite news|url=http://africa.reuters.com/top/news/usnJOE4AT06A.html|title=Zimbabwe says cholera epidemic may spread with rain|date=30 November 2008|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=2008-12-03}}</ref> On 4 December, [[Oxfam]] estimated that by the end of March 2009, some 60,000 would be infected.<ref name=oxfam>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e8d897e4-c0db-11dd-b0a8-000077b07658.html|title=Cholera death rate multiplies in Zimbabwe's economic crisis|date=03 Dec 2008|publisher=Financial Times (UK)|accessdate=2008-12-04}}</ref> By 7 December, Oxfam had revised their estimate to 60,000 cases by the end of January 2009 and a 10% fatality rate,<ref name=oxfam2>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/zimbabwe/3660739/Zimbabwes-cholera-victims-ten-times-more-likely-to-die.html|title=Zimbabwe's cholera victims 'ten times more likely to die'|date=07 Dec 2008|publisher=Telegraph (UK)|accessdate=2008-12-08 | location=London | first1=Sebastien | last1=Berger | first2=Peta | last2=Thornycroft}}</ref> with [[UNICEF]] giving a similar estimate.<ref name=cholerajump>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7769642.stm|title=Zimbabwe 'set for cholera jump'|date=06 Dec 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2008-12-06}}</ref> On 4 December 2008, the [[government of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe government]] declared the outbreak to be a national emergency.<ref name=emergency/>
== Politicisation == As the outbreak and health crisis grew worse, American and British leaders cited the crisis as further proof that it was, in their view, "well past time for (President) [[Robert Mugabe]] to leave"<ref name=crash>{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=vn20081207085716656C601892|title=Zimbabwe crashes|date=07 Dec 2008|publisher=Independent Online (South Africa)|accessdate=2008-12-07}}</ref> and that Zimbabwe had become a [[failed state]].<ref name=closeborder>{{cite news|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N11402094.htm|title=Zimbabwe neighbors should seal borders-US official|date=11 Dec 2008|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=2008-12-12}}</ref> The [[Government of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe government]] and state media responded by blaming the outbreak on European and American sanctions<ref name=resign>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2008/12/2008127103521496227.html|title=Calls mount for Mugabe to resign |date=07 Dec 2008|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=2008-12-07}}</ref> and accused Britain of plotting an invasion under the cover of the outbreak.<ref name=invade>{{cite news|url=http://africa.reuters.com/wire/news/usnL7455762.html|title=Britain plots Zimbabwe invasion â Mugabe spokesman|date=07 Dec 2008|publisher=Reuters|accessdate= 2008-12-07}}</ref> Information minister [[Sikhanyiso Ndlovu]] blamed the cholera deaths on Western sanctions, saying "the cholera issue has been used to drive a wedge among us".<ref name=beyondcontrol>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Zimbabwe-Cholera-Crisis-New-Evidence-Of-Disease-Sweeping-Across-Robert-Mugabes-Country/Article/200812215175175?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_8&lid=ARTICLE_15175175_Zimbabwe_Cholera_Crisis%3A_New_Evidence_Of_Disease_Sweeping_Across_Robert_Mugabes_Country|title=Zim Cholera 'Is Beyond Control'|date=9 Dec 2008|publisher=Sky News (UK)|accessdate=2008-12-10}}</ref> On December 12, Ndlovu repeated his accusation, and claimed that the cholera outbreak was actually a "serious biological-chemical weapon" attack by the [[United Kingdom]], which Ndlovu asserted was trying to commit [[genocide]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2008/12/20081212112525295564.html|title=Zimbabwe blames cholera on Britain|date=12 Dec 2008|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=2008-12-12}}</ref> Said Ndlovu:
{{quote|Cholera is a calculated, racist, terrorist attack on Zimbabwe by the unrepentant former colonial power, which has enlisted support from its American and Western allies so that they can invade the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/12/12/zimbabwe.mugabe/index.html|title=Zimbabwe: Cholera is genocide by UK|date=12 Dec 2008|publisher=CNN|accessdate=2008-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7780728.stm|title=UK caused cholera, says Zimbabwe|date=12 Dec 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2008-12-12}}</ref>}}
In the meantime, a senior [[ZANU-PF]] official argued that the government and party leadership was more focussed on the forthcoming ZANU-PF conference than on the current crisis.<ref name=conference>{{cite news|url=http://www.iwpr.net/?p=zim&s=f&o=348282&apc_state=henh|title=Mugabe Allies Squash Succession Rumours|date=04 Dec 2008|publisher=institute for war & peace reporting|accessdate=2008-12-07}}</ref> On 11 December 2008, President Robert Mugabe made a speech screened on national television in which he said:
{{quote|I am happy to say our doctors have been assisted by others and WHO (the World Health Organization)... so now that there is no cholera... Because of cholera, [[Gordon Brown|Mr Brown]] wants a military intervention... [[George W. Bush|Bush]] wants military intervention because of cholera... There is no cause for war any more. The cholera cause doesnât exist any more.<ref name=over/><ref name=nocholera>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article5323595.ece|title=Mugabe: 'There is no cholera in Zimbabwe'|date=11 Dec 2008|publisher=The Times (UK)|accessdate=2008-12-11 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Fletcher}}</ref>}}
Reports from the [[World Health Organisation|WHO]] contradicted Mugabeâs view and indicated a growing death toll. According to the WHO, as of 8 December nearly 800 people had died of cholera and more than 16,000 cases were being treated.<ref name =over>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7777178.stm|title=Zimbabwe cholera is over â Mugabe|date=11 Dec 2008| publisher=BBC|accessdate=2008-12-11}}</ref> Later that same day, Zimbabwean visas were denied to six French aid workers, including three crisis management specialists, two [[epidemiology|epidemiologists]] and a [[water treatment]] expert.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/PANA-7M8EML?OpenDocument&RSS20=02|title=France says Zimbabwe denies visas to aid workers|date=11 Dec 2008|publisher=Reuters via ReliefWeb|accessdate=2008-12-11}}</ref> Britain's Africa minister, [[Mark Malloch-Brown]], dismissed Mugabe's claim that the Zimbabwe cholera crisis is over, commenting as follows:
{{quote|I don't know what world he [Mugabe] is living in. There is a raging humanitarian crisis in Zimbabwe as well as an economic crisis and still there is no representative government able to lead the country out of this disaster.<ref name=yescholera>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/dec/11/zimbabwe-cholera-robert-mugabe|title=UK dismisses Mugabe's claim that Zimbabwe cholera crisis is over|date=11 Dec 2008|publisher=The Guardian (UK)|accessdate=2008-12-12 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Tran}}</ref>}}
The [[Government of France|French]] foreign ministry and [[USAID]] also contradicted Mugabe's statements and called on him to allow aid to reach the people in need.<ref name=closeborder/><ref name=yescholera/>

By 7 December, [[UNICEF]] had secured sufficient international donor funding to provide sufficient water treatment chemicals for three weeks water supply for Harare and had arranged a shipment of chemical sufficient for four months supply.<ref name=oxfam2/> UNICEF distributed 360,000 litres of water per day in Harare, as well as handing out soap and buckets.<ref name=overwhelmed/> Notwithstanding the contributions received, UNICEF indicated on 9 December 2008 that US$17,500,000 was needed to respond properly to the outbreak.<ref name=descent>{{cite news|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900sid/MCOI-7M8MGB?OpenDocument&rc=1&emid=ACOS-635PHU|title=Zimbabwe: Tracking the Descent|date=11 Dec 2008|publisher=ReliefWeb|accessdate=2008-12-12}}</ref> As of 15 December, following agreement with the Zimbabwe government, the [[World Health Organization]] was procuring medical supplies to roll out a response plan to run health centres.<ref name=tollup>{{cite news|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/MYAI-7MD5EL?OpenDocument&rc=1&emid=ACOS-635PHU|title=Zimbabwe cholera death toll nears 1,000, UN reports|date=15 Dec 2008|publisher=United Nations News Service|accessdate=2008-12-16}}</ref>
==Spread beyond Zimbabwe== [[Image:Spread of Zimbabwean Cholera Outbreak.svg|350px|thumb|right|Spread of cholera within southern Africa, as of 10 February 2009. Not all cases are part of the 2008â2009 Zimbabwean cholera outbreak. <br>'''Key:'''<br><font color=red>â</font> Deaths recorded<br> <font color=orange>â</font> Infections recorded]] The cholera outbreak spread during 2008 to districts in [[Botswana]], [[Mozambique]], [[South Africa]] and [[Zambia]] bordering Zimbabwe.<ref name= Milliband/><ref name=collapse/>
===South Africa=== The outbreak spread to the Zimbabwean migrant worker community in [[Limpopo]] and [[Mpumalanga]] provinces of South Africa<ref name=crosses>{{cite news|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/4d2d97e46fa9854480cd3d665a8a49bf.htm|title=SOUTH AFRICA-ZIMBABWE: Cholera crosses the border too|date=19 Nov 2008|publisher= IRIN via Reuters|accessdate=2008-11-19}}</ref> and cholera bacteria were detected in the [[Limpopo River]] on 3 December 2008.<ref name=descent/> By 12 December 2008 11 deaths and 859 infections had been recorded in South Africa.<ref name=bulletin12dec>{{cite news|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/EGUA-7MCQLR?OpenDocument&rc=1&emid=ACOS-635PHU|title=Zimbabwe health cluster weekly bulletin No. 2 - 12 Dec 2008|date=12 Dec 2008|publisher=World Health Organisation|accessdate=2008-12-16}}</ref> This rose to 2,100 cases and 15 deaths by 14 January 2009<ref name=neighboursrise>{{cite news|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5inUrjOec8guxoAGDFfCrqaftxyMQ|title=Zimbabwe cholera surges as neighbours report rising cases|date=15 Jan 2009|publisher=AFP|accessdate=2009-01-15}}</ref> and to 12,000 cases and 59 deaths by March 10.<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gLRGT2fcbFvRKCiIagnxkaRGodHA AFP S.Africa cholera outbreak 'declining']</ref>
The [[South African government]] set up medical facilities and drinking water supplies at the [[Beitbridge]] border post<ref name=border>{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=vn20081204051853844C776011|title=SAâZim border under close watch |date=04 Dec 2008|publisher=Independent Online (South Africa)| accessdate=2008-12-04}}</ref> and deployed the National Outbreak Response Team and additional medical personnel to [[Musina]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Statement by Minister of Health Barbara Hogan on the outbreak of cholera in Zimbabwe and South Africa|url=http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/2008/08112711451003.htm|date=26 Nov 2008|publisher=SA Government Information Service|accessdate=2009-01-22}}</ref> [[Anthony Turton]], a [[political scientist]] and Unit Fellow with the [[Council for Scientific and Industrial Research]] (CSIR) in South Africa, who had earlier warned of the risk of cholera in South Africa and wrote a report that recommended that the South African government increase its spending on water treatments lest a cholera outbreak occur in the country,<ref name="environment.co.za"/> was suspended for having made "inappropriate statements to the media".<ref name=turton>{{cite news| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7752682.stm|title=South Africa at risk of cholera|date=27 Nov 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate= 2008-12-09}}</ref> On 10 December 2008, the Limpopo Provincial Government declared [[Vhembe District Municipality]], which borders Zimbabwe at Beitbridge, [[Matabeleland South]] province, a disaster area.<ref name=nocholera/> On a 28 January 2009 visit to [[Musina]] with high-ranking [[Government of South Africa|government]] and [[African National Congress|ruling party]] officials, [[South African Health Ministry|Health Minister]] [[Barbara Hogan]] said {{quote|Cholera is spreading... We are beginning to see a shift from Zimbabwe to South Africa. The situation is scary... I am concerned about the impact this is having on our provinces.<ref name=scary>{{cite news|title=Cholera situation is âscaryâ, says Hogan|date=28 Jan 2009|publisher=The Times (South Africa)|url=http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=926867|accessdate=2009-01-29}}</ref> }}
===Other countries=== The spread of the outbreak to Zimbabwe's other neighbouring countries was initially slower than in South Africa, with one death recorded in [[Districts of Zambia#Lusaka Province|Kafue District]] in Zambia and none in Botswana or [[Namibia]] by 9 December 2008.<ref name= redalert/> However as 2009 came, cases have increased, with 4,354 cases and 55 deaths reported by 10 February 2009 in Zambia and 1,596 cases and 14 deaths in [[Katanga Province|Katanga]], the southernmost province of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|DR Congo]].<ref name=rel>{{cite web|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/EGUA-7PKQ35?OpenDocument|title=Africa weekly emergency situation update Vol. 2, No. 8|author=[[World Health Organization]]|publisher=ReliefWeb|accessdate=2009-02-28}}</ref> In Mozambique, cholera has spread to 10 out of 11 provinces,<ref name=rel/> with a total of 9,533 cases by 1 Jan to 1 Mar 2009 and 119 deaths by March 17 <ref name="afp119">[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iUhFqAALo1-pIJv3OKCajIZW0Jsw AFP:12 Mozambican prisoners die after cholera riot]</ref> â as well as the deaths of four health workers in a mob attack, blamed on "misinformation and misunderstanding in efforts to combat cholera".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.apanews.net/apa.php?page=show_article_eng&id_article=90608|publisher=APAnews|title=Mob kills health workers in Mozambique over cholera deaths|date=3 Mar 2009|accessdate=2009-03-03}}</ref> with 12 of the prisoners from the incident having died in jail.<ref name="afp119"/> In Malawi 104 deaths were recorded since January, making it the worst outbreak since 2001-2002 where 960 people died.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE52J0KJ20090320|publisher=Reuters|title=Malawi: Malawi says cholera outbreak kills 104|date=20 Mar 2009|accessdate=2009-03-22}}</ref> Southern Africa is not the only outbreak of cholera in Africa, Kenya, Somalia, Tanzania, DRC, and Ghana have had unrelated cholera outbreaks with between 10-100 deaths in 2009 as of February.<ref name=rel/>
